Key Match Events: Jos Buttler (80no) and Alex Hales (86no) shared a superb opening stand to see England reach the target of 169 with four overs to spare.
Chris Jordan (3-43) was the pick of the bowlers on his return to the side.
Hardik Pandya fired five sixes in an excellent 63 from just 33 deliveries.
Virat Kohli made a half-century before being dismissed by Chris Jordan.
Hales brought up 50 from 28 balls and Buttler reached his half-century from 36 deliveries.
Hales blasted seven sixes in his unbeaten 86 from 47 balls.
Hales and Buttler put on an unbeaten 170-run stand.
Chris Woakes found the edge of KL Rahul (5) which presented a simple catch for Buttler.
Rohit Sharma (27) was removed by a smart catch from Sam Curran in Jordan’s first over.
Adil Rashid (1-20) claimed the key wicket of Suryakumar Yadav (14).
Pandya and Kohli put on 61 for the third wicket until Kohli was dismissed after reaching his 50.
Rishabh Pant (6) fell in the final over and Pandya was out when he trod on his stumps from the last ball of the innings.
Buttler made three boundaries inside the opening over of England’s reply.
Hales brought up his 50 in the eighth over and continued his aggressive play.
Buttler reached his half-century by pulling Pandya for a six in the 13th over.
Yadav dropped a sliced shot from Buttler which trickled for another boundary off Mohammed Shami’s bowling.
Buttler blasted Shami over his head two overs later to seal victory in style.
Post-Match Reflections: England captain Jos Buttler: 'The character we have shown ever since [the loss to Ireland] has been [excellent] and we put in our best performance so far, against top-quality opposition as well. We came here very excited, there was a really good feel around the group, and I felt everyone from one to 11 stood up today.'

India captain Rohit Sharma: 'It’s disappointing how we turned up today. We batted pretty well at the backend but we were not good enough with the ball. It was definitely not a wicket where a team should chase that down in 16 overs. With the ball we did not turn up. Knockout stages are about keeping calm and handling pressure and the way we started with the ball was not ideal. It shows we were a little nervy but you have to give credit to England.'
